elements.content: Recent studies on organic–inorganic hybrid perovskites (OIHPs) and ferroelectric metal–organic framework perovskites (MOFPs) reveal their superb performance as highly efficient materials for photovoltaics and ferroelectrics. This has enabled the development of a new generation of optic-electronic-mechanical devices based on green chemistry. However, the fundamental understanding of these polarization-related functionalities is not yet clear, which has hindered the progress in further designing and developing materials with expected properties. In this work, we investigate three MOFPs that have the same Mg­(HCOO)3 – frameworks with different molecular ions: [CH3NH3]­[Mg­(HCOO)3] (MA-MOF), [(CH3)2NH2]­[Mg­(HCOO)3] (DMA-MOF), and [C­(NH2)3]­[Mg­(HCOO)3] (GUA-MOF). Single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction, inelastic neutron spectroscopy, and ab initio molecular dynamics simulations are combined to achieve a detailed description of the three MOFPs’ static and dynamic structures as a function of temperature. Intriguingly, our study reveals that the alignments and motions of the guest molecular ions are highly dependent on the directional hydrogen bonds that link N–H units to the surrounding MgO6 octahedra through the O acceptor from the frameworks. At the same time, the size, dynamic behavior, and alignments of the A-site molecular ions influence the distortive framework structures and their temperature-dependent deformation. Therefore, the mutual interaction between the guest and the framework determines the overall functionalities of the MOFPs. This study indicates that the configuration of the A-site molecular ions and the potential hydrogen bonds are critical to design the polar functionalities in both MOFPs and OIHPs.

Introduction

The term "perovskite" was initially given to the CaTiO3 mineral but quickly came to represent a large class of similar materials with the general formula of ABX 3. Over the past 80 years, the rapid development of inorganic perovskites, especially the discoveries of ferroelectricity in BaTiO3  in the 1940s and the extraordinary piezoelectricity in Pb(Zr,Ti)O3, has changed the world due to their broad applications in electronic technology, energy harvesting, and multifunctional smart devices, such as capacitors, sensors, actuators, and transducers. The general structure of perovskites can be depicted as a B-site cation which is six-fold coordinated by X-site anions to form octahedra. These octahedra are then arranged into a corner-sharing network with the A-site cations located in the cages of the octahedral network. Owing to the chemical diversity of A- and B-site ions, a wide range of important functionalities are achieved within the perovskite structure including dielectricity, ferroelectricity, pyroelectricity, piezoelectricity, multiferroicity, superconductivity, magnetoresistivity, and optoelectronic and electrooptic properties.

elements.content: Recently, introducing organic components into a perovskite structure has led to the emergence of a new catalogue of materials as organic–inorganic hybrid perovskites (OIHPs). Since the discovery of [CH3NH3]­PbI3 and its prominent photovoltaic performance, OIHPs have attracted intense attention due to their low cost, easy fabrication, and record-high power conversion efficiency (PCE) of solar cells via modifying lead-halide analogues. As the methylamine ion replaces the traditional metal ions, the high PCE behaviors are suggested to be associated with the dynamics of the A-site ions as well as the interactions with the PbI6 framework, but the underlying mechanisms remain elusive. Similar to the A-site, it is also possible to substitute the X-site of the monatomic anions (e.g., O2– and I–) with the organic linkers such as HCOO–, enabling a family of metal–organic framework perovskites (MOFPs). The extended organic linkers increase the size of the A-site cavity, which further expands the candidate pools of the A-site molecular ions. As for the B-site, options ranging from alkali-earth metals to transition or rare-earth metal elements are available, potentially offering a route to avoid environmentally unfavorable heavy metal atoms, such as Pb. Therefore, the MOFPs could combine the merits of both inorganic and organic building blocks in a single compound, enabling unlimited candidates for A-, B-, and X-sites. This opens up a new route to explore specific properties by tailoring the guest–host interactions.

elements.content: For traditional inorganic perovskites like PbTiO3, the lone pair of Pb2+ at the A-site endows it with a significant off-center displacement, generating large spontaneous polarization. This makes PbTiO3 the cornerstone for developing industrially important materials such as the piezoelectric materials Pb­(Zr,Ti)­O3 and the electrooptic materials (Pb,La)­(Zr,Ti)­O3. In OIHPs and MOFPs, the A-site molecular ions possess more degrees of freedom than the cations in their inorganic counterparts, and their interaction with the BX 3 framework involves directional hydrogen bonds which are absent in purely inorganic perovskites. In a very recent work, Allen et al. have addressed the importance of hydrogen bonding, dipolar interaction, and especially the distortive strain from the framework to realize the ferroelectricity in dabconium hybrid perovskites via Monte Carlo simulation. Hence, to unveil the origins of polarization in OIHPs and MOFPs, it is essential to understand both the static structure and dynamics of the A-site ligands and parent frameworks as well as the coupling between them. For this purpose, we selected three MOFPs with different A-site amines, namely, [CH3NH3]­[Mg­(HCOO)3] (methylammonium, MA-MOF), [(CH3)2NH2]­[Mg­(HCOO)3] (dimethylammonium, DMA-MOF), and [C­(NH2)3]­[Mg­(HCOO)3] (guanidinium, GUA-MOF). By a combination of single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) and X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD), inelastic neutron scattering (INS), and density functional theory molecular dynamics (DFT–MD) simulation, we investigated and established the link between dielectric properties with the polar nature and alignments of the A-site molecular ions, as well as the distortion of the parent frameworks.

The three compounds (MA-MOF, DMA-MOF, and GUA-MOF) were synthesized by mild solution methods. Taking MA-MOF as an example, it was prepared as follows: 25.8 mL of HCOOH (89%, 600 mmol) solution was added to the solution of CH3NH2·HCl (2.04 g, 30 mmol) in the component solvent of C2H5OH/dimethylformamide (200 mL, 1:1 ratio). The program SAINT was used for the integration of the diffraction profiles. The structure was solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method with SHELXL. Metal atoms were located from the electron density maps, and other non-hydrogen atoms were located in successive Fourier analyses and refined with anisotropic thermal parameters on F 2. Hydrogen atoms were attached to the specific C and N atoms, and their thermal parameters were refined isotropically. The crystallographic data can be obtained from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. (CCDC nos. 1868020-1868025). The temperature-dependent unit cell parameters were extracted by the cyclic Le-Bail fitting of the obtained diffraction patterns via the Jana2006/Jana2020 software.

elements.content: INS and quasi-elastic neutron scattering (QENS) experiments were conducted on a PELICAN time-of-flight neutron spectrometer at the Australian Centre for Neutron Scattering with the incident neutron wavelength λ of 5.96 Å. Powder samples of MA-MOF, DMA-MOF, and GUA-MOF were placed in annular aluminum sample cans, which were placed in a closed-cycle top-loading cryostat. A vanadium standard measured at room temperature was used to determine the energy resolution (fwhm of 63 μeV) of the instrument. The Q-range for QENS is covered from 0.4 to 1.6 Å–1. All data were normalized to the signal from the vanadium standard to correct the per pixel efficiency on the area detector. The background was subtracted using scans of an empty aluminum sample can under identical conditions. The data reduction and manipulation were conducted via the Large Array Manipulation Program (LAMP). The Q-dependent QENS spectra were fitted using the StrFIT package within LAMP through convoluting the model spectra with the measured resolution function.

elements.content: DFT was performed using the VASP 5.2.1 software suite. The Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof version of the generalized gradient approximation was used for the exchange functional. The energy cutoff was set to 495 eV. To model van der Waals interactions, Grimme’s D2 potential was used. Calculations were performed using a single k-point positioned at the Γ point (0,0,0). The starting models were constructed from the single-crystal structures, assuming one of the possible molecular configurations. Each MOD (DMA, GUA, MA) had 80–150 atoms in the calculation. The ensemble was initially relaxed for 3 ps using a simple isostat where the velocities were rescaled at each iteration to reproduce the correct overall temperature. After equilibration, production runs were performed using the Nosé-Hoover type of isostat for a total of 20 ps using a time step of 1 femtosecond. Runs were performed at 300 K. The trajectories were analyzed using nMOLDYN to extract the cartesian density of states and the mean-squared displacements. These were weighted by the neutron cross sections to facilitate comparison with the experimental data.

elements.content: In addition to the intrinsic properties such as size and geometric structure, the alignments of the A-site ions within the frameworks are critical to the dielectric properties. To elucidate how the molecule framework coupling affects the time-averaged, that is, the static structure, the crystal structure of the three MOFPs was investigated by SCXRD, and the results are summarized in Tables S1 and S2. The space groups of MA-MOF, DMA-MOF, and GUA-MOF at room temperature were assigned to Pnma, R-3c, and Pnna, respectively. The Mg­(HCOO)3 – frameworks of the three MOFPs are distorted in different ways with respect to the parent Pm-3m aristo-type perovskite structure to accommodate the ammonium ions (Figure S1). With the help of symmetry-mode analysis, different distortive modes among the three MOFPs are identified, and the details are summarized in Table S3. Referring to the distortive modes enumerated by Boström et al., the MgO6 octahedra in DMA-MOF display antiphase (a –) tilting around three equivalent [0 0 1]p directions, which is analogous to the Glazer notation a – a – a – in inorganic perovskites. Antiphase octahedral tilting is also observed in MA-MOF and GUA-MOF, but instead of around three [0 0 1]p directions, the a – tilting in these two structures occurs around two of the [0 0 1]p directions, that is, the resultant a – b 0 a – tilting system. In MA-MOF, an additional in-phase (a +) tilt around ⟨0 1 0⟩p leads to the final structure of the framework showing the a – b + a – tilting distortion. In GUA-MOF, an additional distortive mode is associated with the distortion within layers rather than the octahedral tilting (Figure S1d,e). Within one single Mg­(HCOO)3 – layer, the O and C of the MOF linkers displace in the opposite direction, and for the adjacent layer along the ⟨0 1 0⟩p direction, the displacements of these C and O atoms flip signs but remain at the same amplitudes.

elements.content: The A-site ions reside in framework cavities and provide overall electroneutrality. In addition to the nondirectional electrostatic interactions between the molecular cations and the net negatively charged Mg­(HCOO)3 – framework, highly directional hydrogen bonds play a critical role in the alignment of the ammonium components. elements.content: The evolution of the lattice parameters as a function of temperature is summarized in Figure S4. For both MA-MOF and GUA-MOF, the lattice parameters present a continuous change when cooling down from room temperature. It is found that their a- and b-axes exhibit positive thermal expansions, while their c-axes show a negative thermal expansion. Because three MOFPs exhibit different symmetries and axis settings, it is difficult to compare the lattice parameters and associated temperature-dependent behavior directly. b plots the lattice parameters of the primitive perovskite unit cell, which are calculated from the axis relationship listed in Table S3. Both MA-MOF and GUA-MOF have a monoclinic primitive cell with a p = c p ≠ b p and αp = γp = 90° ≠ βp. Moreover, their a p and b p values present an almost linear temperature dependence, and the thermal expansion coefficients are estimated to be 22.6(4) MK–1 (MA-MOF) and 11.4(4) MK–1 (GUA-MOF) along the a p/c p-axis and 23.7(4) MK–1 (MA-MOF) and 23.2(7) MK–1 (GUA-MOF) along the b p-axis. In other words, the thermal expansion of MA-MOF is almost isotropic along the three [0 0 1]p directions, while GUA-MOF experiences faster thermal expansion along the b p-axis. Intriguingly, the evolution of βp for MA-MOF and GUA-MOF has an opposite trend. The βp of two MOF samples can be treated as the hinge angle under the simplified “hinge-strut” architecture where the HCOO– ligand and the Mg2+ cation present the hinge and strut, respectively. However, it is noteworthy that the βp used in this study is the supplementary angle of the hinge angle θ proposed by Collings et al. in perovskite-like formates. The shape of the A-site molecular ions significantly affects the evolution of hinge angles as a function of temperature. The prolate cations such as MA ions display the opposite trend in comparison with the oblate GUA ion according to the framework hinging mechanism. For DMA-MOF, its R phase structure contains a rhombohedral primitive cell (a p = c p = b p, αp = βp = γp ≠ 90°), while the M phase has a triclinic primitive cell with the relationship: a p = c p ≠ b p and αp = γp ≠ βp. The thermal expansion coefficients are estimated to be 27.5(5) MK–1 (R phase) along three equivalent [0 0 1]p directions, 14.9(7) MK–1 (M phase) along the ⟨1 0 0⟩p/⟨0 0 1⟩p direction, and 9.5(4) MK–1 (M phase) along the ⟨0 1 0⟩p direction. Additionally, when the R phase transfers into the M phase, the equivalent cell angle splits into two different values (middle panel of b). With further decreasing temperature, the αp/γp angle of the M-phase remains almost unchanged, while the βp angle gradually increases. Despite the primitive cell parameters of the three MOFPs exhibiting different trends when cooling down from room temperature, the cell volumes of the three samples display contractions during this process.

elements.content: In MA-MOF, all four proposed motions of MA molecular ions can lead to reasonable fits of experimental EISF data. The trajectories of the free tumbling and π-flips motion will form sizable spheres and circles, requiring to overcome large energy barriers induced by the framework. Instead, the fitting suggests internal rotation of the methyl group with τ ∼ 5 ps at 300 K, which is quite similar to the rotation around the C 3 axis of the MA ion obtained in CH3NH3PbI3. Another reasonable model of MA ions is the realignment among discrete orientations (“cage edges”). However, this motion requires four equally energetic sites within one primitive perovskite unit cell, which is incompatible with the deformed MgO6 octahedra. The low-temperature data have a narrower Lorentzian peak, indicating that the movements of molecular ions become sluggish. Additionally, the calculated EISF from the 200 K data (Figure S5d) has a feature similar to that collected at 300 K, indicating no significant change for the detected atomic motions within the temperature ranging from 200 to 300 K. In DMA-MOF, the scenario becomes more complicated. The DMA ion has a larger geometric size than MA, and it is therefore more tightly constrained in the A-site cavity. Among the motions proposed in Figure S5c, all except the π-flips motion could induce reasonable fits to the experimental EISF data. Furthermore, the R-3c symmetry for DMA-MOF indicates that the DMA ions are disordered at room temperature, uniformly distributed with respect to 120° reorientation around the three-fold symmetry axis (edge-to-edge rotation in this case). As shown in f, the edge-to-edge rotation results in a reasonable fit with τ estimated around 9.5 ps. However, the derived timescale contradicts the previous protonated NMR investigations on analogous metal formate materials. Moreover, such a motion is still observable when cooling down to 200 K, reflected by the experimental EISF (Figure S5e).

DFT–MD results indicate that atoms associated with the framework do not undergo large-scale motion, simply vibrating around their equilibrium positions with high frequency (Figure S7a). The distribution of Mg–Mg distances linked by HCOO– and the bond angles ∠OCO formed by the linker C and the two connected O are plotted in Figure S7b,c. These histograms can be fitted by one or two Gaussian functions, and the fitting parameters (mean value μ and standard deviation σ) as well as the results derived from the SCXRD experimental data are summarized in Table S7. The mean values calculated from DFT–MD exhibit solid agreement with those extracted from SCXRD, further confirming the validity of the theoretical calculation. Furthermore, σ values for the three MOFPs are within a similar range, which is indicative of the comparable amplitudes of the thermal vibrations of the three distorted frameworks. Thus, the different A-site environments among the three MOF structures are mainly determined by the static structure of the frameworks rather than their thermal vibrations.

elements.content: While the relatively slow dynamics of the A-site guest molecules has been discussed through QENS, the fast vibrational dynamics for the systems will be illustrated by the generalized phonon density of states (GDOS) shown in for the three MOFPs. The GDOS calculated by DFT–MD (300 K) is also shown in reasonable agreement with the experimental data. For MA-MOF, no evident change can be identified over the temperature range of 100–300 K with respect to both the peak positions and the overall features. For DMA-MOF, the broad bands around 12 and 22 meV measured at 300 K split into two peaks with lowering temperature. This observation is consistent with the order to disorder phase transition illustrated by both the temperature-dependent XRPD and the dielectric property. Clear peak-shifting features (softening or hardening) have been observed for both DMA-MOF and GUA-MOF as a function of temperature as shown in b,c, respectively. This temperature dependence indicates strong anharmonic lattice dynamics as a result of strong interactions between the guest and the framework for the two systems. The different interactions revealed by the GDOS have also been demonstrated by the QENS results. The hwhm of the QENS profile for MA-MOF is double the value of that of DMA-MOF, and there is no measurable QENS broadening for GUA-MOF. This observation correlates with the relative strength of the guest–host interactions. Less interaction means more freedom, thus leading to larger QENS broadening. This guest–host interaction also plays an important role in the dielectric properties. The weak interaction in MA-MOF is responsible for the temperature dependence of the dielectric property. For DMA-MOF, the competition between the guest–host interaction and the thermal energy causes the order–disorder phase transition, thus giving rise to the dramatic change in dielectric spectra with strong frequency dispersion during the phase transition process. For GUA-MOF, the guest–host interaction is much stronger than the thermal energy in this temperature range, bringing a very weak temperature dependence of the dielectric constant. The initial slight decrease with lowering temperature around 300 K may be due to the sufficient thermal energy, and the increase with lowering temperature after 200 K is mainly governed by the guest–host interaction.

Discussion

Based on the above results, the frameworks distort differently to accommodate the specific A-site molecular ions. In turn, the coordination environments provided by the frameworks impact the alignments of the A-site molecular ions via the N-H⋅⋅⋅O bonds. elements.content: For MA-MOF, the time-averaged structure suggests that there is one bifurcated H-bond that bridges the framework and the MA ion. The dynamic structure reveals this HN1A being hydrogen bonded to one framework oxygen at a time, hopping rapidly between two configurations at room temperature. The interactions between the MA ions and the Mg­(HCOO)− framework are quite weak, as reflected by the GDOS results. Therefore, the molecular polar axis (and thus dipole moment) of MA ions present a large thermal oscillation. With decreasing thermal energy, this oscillating polarization becomes frozen, and hence the dielectric constant decreases almost linearly with the temperature. To accommodate the alignments and freezing of the MA ions, the βp angle of the primitive cell increases with lowering temperature. With temperatures below 150 K, the thermal energy cannot trigger the two-site jump motion of HN1A, and only one N1–HN1A···O bond is populated. Therefore, the small dielectric anomaly of MA-MOF is likely to be related to the order–disorder transition of HN1A. At the low temperature, the single N1–HN1A···O hydrogen bond breaks the symmetry between two counter O ions, affecting the antiphase octahedral tilting around the [1 0 1]p direction. To accommodate this energy change for both MA ions and frameworks, MA-MOF transfers into an incommensurate phase, showing the similar behavior reported in [CH3NH3]­[Co­(HCOO)3]. Although at room temperature, the dipole moment arising from the MA ion within one parent perovskite unit cell exhibits fluctuations, the coordination environment presented by the distorted MOF framework constrains the overall orientational sense of the MA ions to antiparallel alignments. Therefore, no spontaneous polarization can be obtained on average. In the case of DMA-MOF, the antiphase tilting of MgO6 generates three symmetry-equivalent sites for N to attach through N–H···O connections. Therefore, although the orientation of the C–N dipole moment of a single DMA ion is clearly defined over time scales of 20 ps or more, its alignment deduced from SCXRD is either temporally or spatially disordered. The fact that a dielectric anomaly appears at lower temperatures suggests that the disorder is from site hopping. The thermal energy cannot break the associated hydrogen bonds, and individual N atoms begin to freeze into a single unique site. As the DMA ion links with the framework through two hydrogen bonds, one of the three primitive cell axes, the b p-axis in this work, then becomes unique. Considering the triangular geometry of the DMA ion, the αp and γp angles will experience a sudden decrease during the R-to-M phase transition. The order–disorder phase transition is also reflected by the GDOS results, and the strong guest–host interaction over the thermal energy forces the ordered structure in DMA-MOF. For GUA-MOF, the A-site ion is tightly restricted by the MOF framework, presenting a strong guest–host interaction. Thus, its dielectric constant is found to be stable over a broad temperature range. With thermal contraction shrinking the size of the A-site cavity, the interaction between the N–H and six MOF framework oxygens is further enhanced, reflected by its strong anharmonic lattice dynamics. Such competition between the guest–host interaction and the thermal energy possibly explains the increase of the dielectric constant at lower temperatures, while the detailed mechanism still needs further investigation. The GUA ion has a planar geometry and alternative alignments along the b p-axis. Thus GUA-MOF exhibits a larger thermal expansion coefficient along the ⟨0 1 0⟩p direction than the other two [0 0 1]p directions. Moreover, the planar geometry and the enhanced hydrogen bonds follow the framework hinging mechanism, which is the reason that the βp angle of the primitive cell presents an opposite trend compared with that of MA-MOF.

QENS and DFT–MD calculations identified active internal rotation of methyl groups in MA and DMA ions of MA/DMA-MOF. Analyses of both static and dynamic structures reveal that the orientation of the A-site molecular ions is highly dependent on the distortions of the eight surrounded MgO6 octahedra which in turn are driven by the gross molecular shape of the A-site ammonium cations as the directional hydrogen bonds rely on the coordination environment of the oxygen. We therefore propose that the structure and nature of hydrogen bonds related to molecular ions can be regarded as the principal factors in designing functional hybrid perovskites. We believe this strategy will become the impetus to investigate the novel functions in other framework materials.

Conclusions

By systematically investigating three MOFPs, MA-MOF, DMA-MOF, and GUA-MOF, it was found that the properties are closely related to the alignments of protonated amines within cubic cages. QENS and DFT-MD calculations identified active internal rotation of methyl groups in MA and DMA ions of MA/DMA-MOF. Analyses of both static and dynamic structures reveal that the orientation of the A-site molecular ions is highly dependent on the distortions of the eight surrounded MgO6 octahedra which in turn are driven by the gross molecular shape of the A-site ammonium cations as the directional hydrogen bonds rely on the coordination environment of the oxygen. The prerequisite for the realignments of the A-site molecular ions is that the framework O ions can supply energy-equivalent acceptor sites for N-H⋅⋅⋅O bonds. The present work not only provides a detailed physiochemical view of the inextricable and mutual interactions between the A-site molecular ions and the MOF frameworks in MOFPs, it also highlights their influence on polar functionalities. We therefore propose that the structure and nature of hydrogen bonds related to molecular ions can be regarded as the principal factors in designing functional hybrid perovskites. We believe this strategy will become the impetus to investigate the novel functions in other framework materials.

Syntheses

All solvents and reagents for the syntheses were commercially available and used as received. The three compounds (MA-MOF, DMA-MOF, and GUA-MOF) were synthesized by mild solution methods. Taking MA-MOF as an example, it was prepared as follows: 25.8 mL of HCOOH (89%, 600 mmol) solution was added to the solution of CH3NH2⋅HCl (2.04 g, 30 mmol) in the component solvent of C2H5OH/dimethylformamide (200 mL, 1:1 ratio). After fully mixing, 100 mL of aqueous solution of Mg(NO3)2⋅6H2O (7.69 g, 30 mmol) was added dropwise into the prepared solution. The solution was continuously stirred for about 2 h. The reaction vessel was tightly sealed by the plastic membrane and transferred to an oven. The resultant reaction was left at 60 °C for 2 weeks, and then colorless quadrate block crystals (0.5-2 mm in dimension) of X-ray quality were collected after washing with ethanol and drying in the air (approximate yield ~ 55%). Single crystals of DMA-MOF (triangle prism) and GUA-MOF (octahedron spindle) were obtained by a method similar to that described for MA-MOF by replacing CH3NH2⋅HCl with (CH3)2NH⋅HCl and (NH2)2CNH⋅HCl, respectively (yield ~ ca. 50 and 40%).

The composition of the three MOFPs differs only in the identity of the A-site pronated amines. MA and DMA ions have polar structures, that is, dipole moments, while the structure of the GUA ion yields no polar axis, and instead, it exhibits a hexapole moment. These characteristic components have a strong impact on the bulk properties of these MOFPs. a–c shows the temperature-dependent dielectric responses (the dielectric constant εr and dielectric loss tan δ) of the three MOFPs. For MA-MOF, the dielectric constant monotonically decreases as the temperature (T) is decreased. A noticeable but small dielectric anomaly near 150 K (inset of a) is obtained and possibly related to the commensurate-incommensurate phase transition as reported recently in the analogous [CH3NH3]­[Co­(HCOO)3] single crystal. In the case of DMA-MOF, a steplike dielectric anomaly occurs around 270 K, associated with a strong dielectric relaxation process over the temperature range between 150 and 270 K as reflected by the frequency dispersion of the dielectric constant. The broad dielectric peak indicates an order–disorder phase transition, which is consistent with previous results. The inset plot displays the logarithm of the applied frequency as a function of inverse temperature corresponding to the peak in tan δ spectra. For the low-temperature region, the data can be well fitted by the Arrhenius law f = f 0 exp ⁡ − E a R T Where E a is the activation energy, f 0 is the relaxation frequency constant, and RT is the thermal energy. The fitting results estimate that E a and f 0 are around 0.284 eV and 17 GHz, respectively, which are in the range similar to those for the 120° reorientation of the DMA ion around the C–C axis. In the high-temperature range, the peak of the dielectric losses becomes frequency-independent, which is phenomenologically similar to the ferroelectric-to-paraelectric phase transition with the softening of the phonon modes. c shows the temperature-dependent dielectric properties of GUA-MOF. Its dielectric constant remains almost invariant over a broad temperature range with no evident frequency dispersion. However, it displays the surprising feature that the dielectric constant increases with decreasing temperature, and this trend remains unchanged even at 10 K. This behavior is quite similar to that observed in incipient ferroelectrics such as SrTiO3 and rutile TiO2, although the dielectric constant is several orders of magnitude smaller than those of the other two materials.

The evolution of the lattice parameters as a function of temperature is summarized in Figure S4. For both MA-MOF and GUA-MOF, the lattice parameters present a continuous change when cooling down from room temperature. It is found that their a- and b-axes exhibit positive thermal expansions, while their c-axes show a negative thermal expansion.
